Paper 1 - Differential Phase Shift Keying-Aided Multi-Mode Chirp Spread Spectrum Modulation

Modulation

The conventional CSS incorporates N symbols (or frequency shifts), which is divided into P groups, each containing symbols, implying bits. Then, the un-chirped signals is denoted by [f1(n),â€†â€¦,â€†fP(n)] with .

Then, M-ary phase shift keying symbols are further modified by differential phase shift keying as modulated onto these un-chirped signals, yielding Then, the superimposed un-chirped signal is given by , of which the modulation onto chirps is given by , where vâ€„âˆˆâ€„{u,â€†d} with and , identified by a single bit bv.

Therefore, the number of employed bits is .

Demodulation

The demodulation is composed into three stages: the first for bv, the second for bits, and the third employing the differential property to acquire the symbols. Note that the employed PSK makes the amplitude ambiguous such that only the phase matters.

Defect

  • In this paper, the CSI might be used for denoting the channel gain. However, the computational complexity mainly results from the analysis for delay and Doppler shifts. The computations cost for channel gain is negligible.
  • So we donâ€™t have to consider the differential phase shift keying but the conventional M-ary phase shift keying.

Analysis of employed bits

Without considering the DPSK and up-chirps or down-chirps, the number of the bits within one symbol is rendering the fact that f(P) has a maximum point within [1,â€†N] at . Thus, the maximum point must be located either at or at .

Comparisons

  • PSK-LoRa: Directly modulating PSKs onto single chirp which is not separated, implying logâ€†Nâ€…+â€…logâ€†M bits per symbol.
  • GCSS: Solely separating the symbols into several groups, implying bits per symbol.
  • DM-CSS: The available N symbols are divided into 2 groups, associated with 2 activation bits (1 for 1, -1 for 0), one for odds and the other for evens. Then, the 1 selection bit for up-chirp or down-chirp is used. Overall, the number of bits within one symbol is . [Simplified version of DPSK-MM-CSS]

Paper 2 - Novel Double Slope Frequency Shift Chirp Symbol

There are two encoding methods proposed in this paper. The specific depiction of the two approaches is given as follows.

  • Approach 1 - DSFSC-DCSZ symbols

    • The temporal figure is given as follows:

      where each symbol is composed of two parts, one with up-chirp and the other with down-chirp starting at 0.

  • Approach 2 - DSFSC-DCSMF symbols

    • The temporal figure is given as follows:

      where each symbol also consists of two parts, the first with up-chirp and the second with down-chirp ending at -Vmax.

The demodulation of these waveforms utilizes the temporal instruments, which is not covered.

Paper 3 - Memoryless Continuous-Phase Chirp Spread Spectrum for Mud Pulse Telemetry

This paper considers the estimation for symbol duration and bandwidth under the underwater acoustic scenario. The receiver utilizes a concatenation of algorithms to analytically acquire the corresponding estimates, given as follows.

  • Memoryloss analog nonlinear preprocessor (MANP): suppress the impact of underwater noise (thus neglected).
  • Short-time Fractional Fourier Transform (ST-FRFT): Output an time-frequency image.
  • Edge detection: Convert the color image from TF image into a gray image.
  • Hough Transform: an effective image recognition method for a gray image.
  • Parameter Estimation: Calculate all bandwidth, duration, and chirp rate. Then k-means is employed to classify these parameter sets (by solely using bandwidth).
